Meaning: Used when a man of substance is belittled e.g See how mobile police trash the guy, a whole managing director for dat matter
1. USA or UK 2.Someone who lives in those places.
Deputy exercising power in the absence of the boss.
contraction for I don’t care attitude
Efik soup made from Afang leaves, beef, dried fish, crayfish, palm oil, and periwinkle.
Large traditional garment usually worn by men over a shirt.
Labourer who carries heavy goods for a fee.
Any Government In Power. Derisory term for person who changes alliances as goverments come and go.
Dancing with fanciful footwork. Also called Ajasco Toronto.
One used to butter; rich spoilt kid. See Ajepako.
Literally means -one used to eating wood i.e. uses a wooden chewing stick as toothbrush.
Pap made from corn. See Ogi.
Bean cake made from fried ground black-eyed beans.

1. Recent arrival from abroad (especially UK or USA) into Nigeria
2. Nigerian nickname for an African American
Abbreviation for Alaba International Market, Lagos. Famed for the sale of electrical goods.
It is all a .e.g All na wayo.
Shoes worn all the time, come rain come sunshine.
Shouted when hailing taxi cabs in some states in Nigeria.
Used in place of 'him' or 'her' in sentence e.g. 'Warn am O!'
Dough like meal made from yam flour and hot water. Usually served with Ewedu soup.
1. Gossip 2. Name of a character in a Nigerian soap opera (The village headmaster), with a penchant for gossiping.
Wearing the same clothes or fabric with someone else especially married couple.
One wishing to emigrate out of Nigeria. Term originates from government sponsored advert in which the main character - Andrew threatens to ‘check out’ of the country due to various hardships.
1. Basket 2. Bad goalkeeper in soccer match.
1. Arrive unexpected usually to something good such as a meal. Host will then say 'you waka well o'. 2. Arrive uninvited.
1.Illicit gin. 2.Native gin. Also called Kai Kai, Ogogoro, Push me-push you, Sapele water and Burukutu.
Conjunctivitis. (an epidemic swept Nigeria around the time of the Apollo 11 moon landing hence the name)
1. Make your own arrangements 2. Everyman to himself.
Unemployed street-wise youth loitering in the neighbourhood. Also called 'Alaye boys' in Lagos.
How it e.g. 'Tell am as e take happun'.
Sarcastic reply to irritant question. Also- Askor.
Tradition Yoruba fabric worn on special occasions. Means Upper class cloth.
Not at all. Also- At-all ah-tall.
1. Hanger on 2. Social climber forcing themselves on the in-crowd
Small stool placed along the aisle of luxurious buses for passengers who can't afford proper seats.
Any older female. Used when first name terms not appropriate.
Imported clothes from Europe and America; especially designer labels. See Sputs, kack and Sputeez
Derisory name for a person suffering from Jiga infestation. Also Baba sore.
Internet pen name of the author of this dictionary.
Large traditional robe worn by man. See Agbada.
Carry a baby tied to the back with lappa
1. Severely e.g Di man wey moto jam wound bad bad. 2. Absolutely e.g She fain bad bad.
1. Name of Igbo vigilante group. 2. Bottom. See Yarnsh.
One who eats greedily. See Long throat.
Soup made from Palm tree fruit.
Beat to the point of death.
On your bike mate. See Hanlele.
Illegal. See Corner-corner, 419 , Jibiti, Wuru wuru and Mago mago.
Second hand clothes. Usually spread on a mat at the roadside. See Okrika wake up.
1. Good times e.g. 'Betta don come'. 2. Improvement e.g. things don betta.
1. There's something good in store. 2. Good times are here.
Long and difficult English words. See Blow Oyinbo.
1. Rich and well connected man 2.Man in position of authority. See Oga.
1. Dog 2. Cooked dog meat. See Four-o-four. 3. Common dog name in Nigeria.
Traditional soap made from Palm oil. Also called Ose Dudu in Yoruba.
Use of skin lightening creams. Also Bleaching.
1 Punch 2 Speak with arrogance e.g. sofri-sofri blow Oyinbo.
Use of long English words especially with a foreign accent.
For Pete's sake e.g. Comot bo! See Ojare and Jare.
Yoruba word for ‘cover your eyes. 1.Hide and seek 2. Pay eye service e.g. Dis Boju-boju friend go stab you for back o! 3. Deception
Yoruba for come down and let's fight and used for over crowded commuter bus in Lagos. See Molue.
To bluff one's way through a situation.
Thug. Derived from Burma boy. Term probably originates from Nigerians who served under the British in Burma during WW2.
1. Frown 2. Disagree e.g. e don bone for am!
Sun glasses. See Everything tinted and Shaded up.
A kind of blackened dried fish used to prepare local soups
Very plenty. See Nyanfu-nyanfu, Full ground remain and Plenti plenti.
Not in touch with one's cultural heritage.
One well dressed up in borrowed clothes. Also Borrowed Baffs.
Treasured attire worn only on important occasions. e.g Dat yua dress na real bottom box o!
Dregs at the bottom of the pot.
Undue favouritism toward's a female lover e.g Na bottom power she use get dat job o!
Large voluminous dress worn by women.
1. Surprised e.g. Man bow! 2. Applaud or be impressed e.g. everybodi bow when I land wit away baffs.
Small bungalow behind main house where hired domestic staff or extended family reside.
Ritual breaking of the Kola nut at the beginning of a ceremony.
Nepotism. See Fren-fren and Who know man.
1. Break e.g Na you broke di plate.2. Speak with big English words e.g Abeg sofri broke the grammar now.
Roadside restaurant.Also- MamaPut and Food is ready.
Iron bars built into windows for security
Grammatical error especially in spoken English. Also Ibon.
Answered prayer. E.g God don butta my bread.
Another name for Ajebota. Also Omobota
1. Reckless driving. 2. Speedily arriving at one's destination i.e. travelling as quickly as an aircraft. See Okada.
Cafeteria. Used mainly on University campuses.
To be beckoned by unseen forces. Juju is usually implied e.g. dem dey call you?
Run full circle and over take fellow athlete in long distance race.
Dead ringer for someone else e.g See im face. Na real carbon copy of im papa.
Unregistered taxi cab operating illegally. Not painted in official taxi colours.
1.Take up too much responsibility for something. 2. To become obsessed with something e.g See how e carry politics for head.
Used playfully to mean -Get away or Get out of here.
verb 1. Womaniser e.g. you too carry woman.
1. Enough salt in food. e.g. salt no catch dis soup at all. 2. Intoxication e.g. Ogogoro don catch am. 3. Excited e.g. Bodi dey catch am.
Sang to the tune of Michael Jackson's You wanna be starting something. (See Tombo)
1 Take advantage of. 2 Intimidate 3 Cheat e.g. abeg no chance me jo!
Fried bits of pastry served as appetiser. See Small chop.
1. Food 2. Income 3. Bribe 4. Embezzle money e.g Dat Oga chop belle-full bifor e retire.
Eat glass. Part of pre fight preamble during which various threats and questions are asked to measure of toughness of the opponent e.g. you dey chop bottle?
Monthly or weekly house keeping allowance.
Used for one was sweats excessively e.g. which one you dey sweat laik Christmas goat. i.e. the goat sweats for its life as Christmas draws near.
1. Prick 2. Stab e.g Why you chuk me naif?
1. Squeeze into tight corner. 2. Getting involved with other peoples buisness.
1. Leave e.g Make you clear commot. 2. Malicious sliding tackle during football game e.g See as them dey clear leg, abi na fight? 3. Finish large meal e.g Di guy clear the Eba finis o!
Grin and bear it e.g close eye drink dat medicine ojare.
Following spouse to every social event for fear of husband or wife snatchers.
Court shoe. Any low cut ladies' shoe not bearing laces.
Derisory term used to describe the mottled complexion one who uses skin bleaching products.
Loose ones mind e.g. Dat guy don dey Colo.
1 Come out 2 Get away! E.g. comot for here jo! 3 Excuse me e.g. comot road make I pass.
Fenced off house, bungalow or groups of huts.
Spoilt beyond repair e.g. see how she juss condemn the moto.
Saying used when one is forced to do the unthinkable due to prevailing financial circumstances.
University Campus Fraternity. See Cult Guy.
1. Control your temper! 2. Title of song by Nigerian saxophonist Lagbaja.
High class begging e.g. A rich man or business with cash flow problems begging for loans.
Very good. e.g Di bobo na correct guy.
Afford e.g You fit count Twenty thousand as you stand so?
1 Passport 2 Right of abode in foreign country.
Rallying cry for everyone in a public building to rise and leave. Usually done to embarrass speaker or performer on university campuses.
Defraud completely e.g. e crape all my money or E don crape my head pata-pata. 2 Finish (food) completely. See Level.
Idleness. e.g see as e cross leg dey wait awoof.
Threat. E.g. you go cry blood today today.
Threat to a child before a smacking. See Trouble dey call you.
Tight and long skirt i.e. it would be difficult to skip across gutter.
One belonging to secret societies, nocturnal fraternities or clubs especially in higher institutions.
Contraction of cunning. Also Cunny or Cuni-cuni. See Wayo

Word: Cuni man die cuni man bury am
Meaning: It takes one to know one.
Share of the loot. Usually involves a bribe.
Dread locks. Also called Bob Marley.
To rudely cut short someone who is speaking . Also Idanminashon.
Slow dance with couple in each other's arms. Also Hold tight.
1. Dress very well e.g Di bobo deck o, ah-ah. 2. Punch to the ground e.g Man go deck you o! 3.To sit down relaxed. E.g See e deck for chair laik na im get am.
Fine clothes. Also Deckeez. See Baffs.
1. Pay for a round of drinks. 2. Buy new item e.g. Di guy don declare new jeep o! Also Declaration and Declare shows.
A group of people with an affiliation such as students or soldiers.
Threat or dare meaning "Don’t even think about it".
Have you been sent to torment me?
1. Is e.g. wetin dey happun 2. Location e.g. where you dey 3. Stance in the matter e.g. which one you dey sef. 4. In existence 5. Spectacular e.g. dat car dey well-well.

( Dele is a Yoruba name) 1. I am barely surviving e.g Man juss Dey laik Dele. 2. Being idle e.g You juss dey there laik Dele . Also - Standing like Standard Bank, Looking like Lucozade and Dey like you no dey.
1 Keep on in self deceit 2 It is there at present.

Word: Di thing wey mai eye see, mi mouth no fit talk am

Meaning: 1.Their 2. Dear or expensive eg Dat moto too dia.
Individual variations on interpreting what is seen.
Assorted e.g Na different different kain fish dey inside dat soup.
Fight e.g We two go dig am out.
(Obsolete as A-Levels no more in place in Nigeria) Gaining admission into University after A-Level examination. JAMB examination not done in this case. See JAMB.
Participate e.g. I no do again. 2. Afflicting one's health e.g. Wetin dey do am?
Show us the colour of your money. See Shake bodi.
Well done. Joke using the word ‘river’ as opposed to ‘well’.
Well done e.g you do well.
1. Avoiding someone 2. Escape e.g. man juss dodge comot.
Acting this way e.g. Why are you doing laik dis now?
1. Has e.g. e don come. 2. Has it? E.g. e don come? 3. Have e.g. I don tell am (present tense) 4. Have e.g. I don been tell am (Past tense).
(Derisory) One in habit of giving their services to others for free. Derived from- donate.
1 Door mat 2 Area in front of main door to house.
dirty slap Hard slap across the face.
Cleaners employed by Lagos state government to clean un block public gutters.
Slimy e.g Di Okra soup draw well well.
1. Withdraw 2. Make hasty exit. 3. Avoiding getting drawn into a dicey situation.
Make an empty boast. Also Rake and Shakara.
1. Any kind of clothing. 2. Move your butt.
1.In trouble e.g. you go drink garri today.2. Meal of garri and water. See Soak garri.
1. A taxi journey e.g Oga, na fifty Naira per drop. 2. To alight from a bus. 3. Pay up 4. Monetary bribe.
1. Make extra copy of music tape 2. Copy neighbour's work during examination.
It is a rarity e.g E dey hard make Saturday night meet am for house.
Meal made with garri and hot water. Usually eaten with soup with bare fingers of right hand. See Garri.
(Abbreviation of economy) Stingy. See Tight hand.

Traditional Efik soup made with beef, stock fish, snails, crayfish, periwinkle, peppers, pumpkin leaves and onions. Usually served with pounded yam or Fufu. Folklore has it that when an Efik maiden prepares this dish for a man she steals his heart away.
1. Sorry 2. What a pity 3. How touching
Tailor walking on the street with his portable sewing machine on his shoulder. Ejika ni is Yoruba for "shoulder is". See Obioma.
1. Get out of control. 2. Drive car into the streets.
Thrift society where members contribute a monthly sum into a pot and then take turns in collecting the total sum. Also-Moni of by turn - by turn.
Abbreviation for term 'essential commodities' i.e. Milk, Sugar, and Salt.
Wearing really dark sun glasses. See Bones and Shaded up.
1. A kind of beans 2. Street hawkers who sell cooked beans.
1. Leaked examination question paper. 2. Contraction of exposed
Rooms rented to families which all open onto a long corridor. Also Room and parlour.
1. Showing off 2. Pretending to be classy.
1. Light plastic football. 2. Neighborhood in Ibadan
(Acronym for Festival of Arts and culture) Name of large estate in Lagos originally built to house participants of the arts festival and later sold to members of the public.
At lightening speed e.g See as the car overtake us fiam.
1. Public fight especially one in which clothes are torn off. 2. Free public spectacle 3. See through clothes.
Possess ability to carry out task.
1. Jump across a fence e.g the tief fly di fence fiam. 2. Jump across open drainage gutter.
Wear shirt with collar turned up. Also- Fly your shirt.
1. Play with. 2. Joke with e.g. I bi yua age wey you wan dey follow mi play?
Derived from Phonetics. To speak in a foreign accent e.g. why you dey blow fone?
1. Buka 2 Wording of sign placed in front of Buka 3. Food is being served.
Derived from Citroen. One who has no car and goes everywhere on foot. See Legedes Benz and Trekeez.
1. From. E.g. Comot for road. 2. At e.g. Na for Tombo bar I see di booze man.
Have an aversion to certain foods e.g. I dey forbid goat meat on Sundays. Usually related to Juju.
No chance in a million! See lai-lai
1. Peugeot 404 2. Cooked dog meat i.e. the dogcatcher needs to be fast to make the kill
Children's birthday party. Usually lasts from 4pm to 6pm.
Presence e.g Who born am to talk dat nonsense for mai front
Dough like meal made from hot water and either cassava or plaintain flour. Usually served with soup
Meaning - Give dem finish. 1. To make a memorable entrance. 2. Dress very well.
Excess e.g. See how food full ground remain for the party. Shoo!
Couple in tight embrace. Also-Gaining electrons.
Garri. Pseudo chemical composition of Gari
Aluminium container for fetching water. Garuwa is used as a metaphor for private business e.g. everybodi carry im Garuwa meaning mind your own business.
1. Own a lot of an item 2. Hoarde.3. To be muscular e.g. See how the man gather. You no bow? 4. Beat up. e.g. See as e gather di man.
1. Rhythmic Afro beat sound 2. Loud sound system.
Yoruba soup made from ground beans, red capsicum, onions, tomatoes and palm oil. Served with Amala, Pounded Yam or Eko.
Electricity generator. Also Standby Gen and Plant.
Brand of sardines in tomato sauce.
1. To have or own e.g. I get shirt like dat. 2. To understand e.g. I don get wetin you dey yarn.
Important information to tell e.g. I get gist for you.
1. Sensible 2. Genuine e.g that deal no get head at all
1 Talkative 2 Acid tongue. 3 Gift of the garb.
1. Right of way while driving e.g. Na mi get road but e come shunt me. 2. Delusions of grandeur e.g. See poor man dey waka as if na im get road.
Intelligence e.g. So you think say na you get sense pass?
Large woven red or blue plastic carrier bag which was used by Ghanaians when they fled Nigeria during a mass deportation exercise.
Give it to him or her.
Examination malpractice were the neck is stretched to spy neighbour's work.
Hair cut with horizontal parting on back of head.
1. Will 2. Indicating intent. (In present tense) e.g. I go beat you O!
See you when you get back.
God will not allow that to happen.
God will not allow that to happen. Also God forbid.
Derived from name of soap character with clean- head. Clean shaven head. See Moro-moro.
Hear through the grapevine. Also Gotten gist and Them say.
1. Takes a fancy to you e.g. di bobo gree yua own o! 2. Agree with you.
I am afraid of you. Also- You dey fear me o.
I have no time for you
Fried unripe plantain chips. See Dodo.
1. Language spoken by the Igbo people of Eastern Nigeria 2. Indian hemp.
Igbo soup made from goat's head (including the mashed brain), vegetables, palm oil and potash. Served as a starter.
I too know. One who thinks they know everything.
Right of abode in a country. See Country paper.
When the ball remains in the weaker team's half of the field during soccer match.
Put your hands above your head.
1. Dry and dusty winds blowing Southwards from the Sahara occurring during the dry season. 2. Financial hardship.

1. Wake up call to action 2. Rallying cry. Used to psyche up people who then respond by shouting Hey! Might have originated from the shouts of workers and their foremen during railway construction in Nigeria. The foreman would have shouted Chaps (or Hey) obey.
On your account. Eg Why you wan dey chop credit for mai head?.
1. Mad 2. Eccentric e.g Why you dress laik yua head no correct. See Craze
1. Understand a language 2. Obey instruction. 3. Comprehend what is being said.
Obey instruction. e.g. you no dey hear word
Frightened e.g. My heart juss cut.
Public cleaner of major roads in Lagos.
sound emitted while sucking ones teeth. Duration is proportional to emotional state ay the time
Prevent hunger e.g Abeg take dis chin-chin hold belle till the yam cook.
Girl sent off to meet husband for first time following arranged marriage.
Well brought up. E.g. e no get home training meaning she wasn't brought up well.
A personal disaster blamed on a family member using Juju to cause problems.
1. How are things with you? 2. How are things going?
How are we going to do it?
What am I supposed to do?
1. Hunger 2. Strong desire for something e.g. New moto dey hungri me. 3. Poor e.g. Look im Byah byah laik hungri man own.
Poor man. see slso Weather man and Suffer man.
1. Very hard worker 2. Worker being taken advantage of.
1. Collision, especially cars. 2. Meet up see also Block.
Joint Admission and Matriculation Board. Body in charge of University entrance in Nigeria who organise a yearly entrance examination.
Nonsense. e.g Ol' boy why you dey talk Jazz laik dat?
Parasitic worm infestation on legs or foot such as Guinea worm. See Baba Jiga.
Johnny juss come. Slang to denote a Nigerian who has just returned from abroad especially after a long absence.
This is no longer funny! Also - If na joke stop am!
Paella like dish of rice made with tomatoes, peppers and spices. A Nigerian party dish.
1. Watering hole where food and drinks are sold.
Say ones side of the story in a dispute.
1. Date election result was annulled in Nigeria. 2. Fraud 3. Election malpractice.
Ajejunle. A rough part of Lagos.
1. Knock-knees 2. Unexpected Complications in a situation 3. Unexpected problems e.g. K-leg don enta di matter.
Dress well. See Sput, Spoot, Baffs and Give dem finis.
Yoruba for ‘Bicycle of Marwa‘. Name given to 3 wheeled vehicle used as Taxi in Lagos. They appeared during the tenure of Gorvenor Marwa.
Strong and stiff. E.g. the stork fish bodi strong Kakaraka laik say dem never cook am.
House of the late Fela Anikulapo Kuti, which was burnt down by soldiers.
1. One armed bandit. 2. Amusement arcade game machines.
1. Kind of African print fabric thought to have originated in the city of the same name the capital of Uganda. Also called Ankara. 2. Jail house.
Large bell bottomed trousers that drags on the floor. See Labu
Phrase meaning 1. Things are getting very tough. 2. Threat to someone telling him that - More trouble than bargained for is on the way.
Quick-quick buses; Yoruba word. Danfo buses known for always being in a hurry.
Make a killing and divide the spoils. Usually refers to corruption among public officers.
1. Literate 2. Intelligent. also see Sabi book.
Trouser that barely reaches ankle. Also Jump up pee.
1. Very clear vision e.g. na for mai two eye korokoro I see am hapun 2. Clear daylight e.g na daytime Korokoro.
1. Cook. 2. To be given protective charms by witch doctor e.g Babalawo don kuk am well well.
Word placed in sentence for emphasis e.g. I no Kuku sabi am, meaning I really don't know him. Also Kukuma.
Small fried balls of peanut paste.
Refreshing Nigerian drink made from Sorghum or Millet. Drunk in Northern Nigeria.
Not in a million years. Also Lai lai to lai lai.
1. Light 2. Electricity e.g. NEPA don commot lait again.
Threat meaning I will slap you face e.g I go land you slap o! Also Wipe and Tear you slap.
Guinness stout drink. Also called Odeku.
Carry someone on your laps during ride in a car or bus.
Use newly brought item for first time.
Someone who seems to always be present e.g. dat bobo leg no dey comot church.
One who goes out too much. Also Waka about and Waka waka

Word: Leg no dey stay one place

Meaning: Derived from Mercedes Benz. Denotes one without a car who 'legs it' everywhere.
(Derived from Lexus). Someone who walks everywhere because they don't own a car. also see Footron.
Result that is barely above the pass mark in examination.
Eat and finish a substantial amount of food. E.g. See as e level di eba.
Before you knew it. Also - No do no do.
Eat too much E.g. E juss load poundi finis come dey ask for eba.
Local organising committee. Usually formed to run a major sporting event.
Looking at things one's eyes are not supposed to see.
Well connected. e.g. na long leg e use enta dat school
Excessive public show of affection by couple.
1. Character in Nigerian soap opera Second Chance famed for wearing large head scarves. 2. Lady with large head-scarf.
Eat food and lick plate clean till Logo at the bottom of plate is visible.
Maggi cubes. Brand of seasoning cubes for cooking containing herbs and spices.
Spell put on woman said to kill her partner if involved in adulterous relationship.
1. Made e.g. Wetin make am sick. 2. Should I? E.g. Wetin make I do? 3. Let me e.g. Make I warn you o! 4. Parade one's self e.g. E juss dey make up and down.
Hand me down clothes from a lady.
Road side food seller so called because customers frequently beg for extra helpings by saying 'Mama abeg put more now'.
Wooden construction on the chassis of a lorry for carry passengers.

Word: Man no die, man no rotten

Meaning: Complications e.g. Dat business don get Many leg.
1. Age group. 2. Same social class. e.g. which day we become mate?
1. Juju 2. Tablets. Also called Melesin and medi.
Mess up e.g Ol’boy, why you kon dey mescaform now?
Abbreviation for Mobile Police force which is a rapid response anti-riot arm of the police. Also called Kill and go (derogatory).
Tailor who slings sewing machine on shoulder and roams the streets in search of clients. Also Obioma.
Steamed cake of ground black eyed beans containing pepper, bits of fish or corned beef. Also spelt Moyin moyin.
1. The iron float refers to large ships and the phrase means it cost money to do anything outstanding. 2. Money can do a lot.
Condition where desires can't be accomplished due to financial constraints.

Word: Monkey dey work babon dey chop
Meaning: The workers don’t partake of the harvest despite their hard work.
Rickety bright yellow bus used for transportation in Lagos.
Cob of roasted or boiled corn.
Show off one's academic prowess. Also Vibrate
1. Die e.g. Di Baba don murd o! 2. Murder e.g. Wo, if you touch mi I go murd you o!
Slang for twenty Naira note which bears the photograph of the late Nigerian Head of state; General Muritala Mohammed. Also called Muri.
1. Rebuff to someone being unduly aggressive. 2. Is it by force?
Exclusive or distinctive item. Eg That Bobo Opon na one.
1. That is true. 2. That is how e.g. Na so e come dabaru everything.
1. Is that how it is now? 2. Is that true?

Word: Na so I see am o!

Meaning: It is wonderful. Also Na wah.
1. What is it this time? 2. So what?
You are the man! Also Na you we dey look o!

Word: Na you we dey look o

Meaning: 1. Pertaining to Nigeria 2. Nigerian citizen e.g. Naija no go change.
1. Tell 2. Hit e.g. Why you nak me for bodi laik dat now? 3. Eat 4. What someone is wearing e.g. See the shoe wey e nak. Natin
National Electric Power Authority. Also Never Expect Power Always.
National Football Association. Also No future ambition.
Soup made from goat intestines, heart, liver, vegetables, onions and pepper. Served as a starter.
Excuse used to explain away failures in Nigerian organisations or government
1. Did not e.g I giam chop e No chop. 2. Will not.
Just count me out of that
Persona non-grata E.g Dat one no bi person.
A lot. E.g. E get money no bi small.
It didn’t start today. e.g No bi today that man begin tief.
Can’t see without touching e.g Dat guy no dey take eye see woman.
Before I could say Jack Robinson.
One way or the other. Also - No do no do.
1. Ignorant or clueless person 2. One with exaggerated ideas about their true station in life.
Do not allow e.g. No let am come here again.
Very large size E.g. Im leg na no size in London.
Placed at end of question for emphasis E.g Wetin dey do you now?
Plenty. See Borku and Plenti plenti.

National Youth Service Corps. One-year compulsory national service undergone by all Nigerian graduates. After an initial 4 week military style training camp the graduates are posted throughout Nigeria to fill various posts. Also Now Your Suffering Commences.
